text:
These were delicious.  I made a simple cream cheese icing to glaze the top and they were very yummy (cream cheese, vanilla, milk, butter, powdered sugar)!  The dough never really "rose" that much during the resting periods, so I dont know if that made much of a difference at all.  I used a 9x13 pan, but there was extra room in the pan, meaning that some of the gooey center oozed out into the empty side of the pan, and then baked hard onto it.  Next time, I'll try an 8x10 pan, or muffin tins.  :)

text:
Rollinâ Rollinâ Rollinâ
Waking up in the morning to a warm ooy gooy cinnamon roll, dripping with cool cream cheese icing is always a perfect way to start any day. This is one of the best cinnamon roll recipes I have found. This is a must try ninety minute cinnamon roll recipe. I am normally intimidated by yeast breads, but this recipe turns out perfect every time. Not only is it a quick and simple way to get your sugar fix, but in the end, the result is sweet and subtly delicious. Yeast bread seems to be an all-day process, but this will be ninety minutes of your life well spent! If you want to treat your family and friends to a special treat, delight them with these delicacies. This recipe yields twelve servingsâ¦.and believe me you will want to double, if not triple this recipe; these go faster than speedy Gonzalez. Although this recipe is delicious on its own, donât just stick to this basic recipe; add some of your own spices such as ginger, ground cloves, nutmeg, and a pinch of cardamom to the cinnamon mixture for an extra kick. This will not only add warmth and depth to the filling, but also fill your house with a heavenly aroma. Once completed indulge in the incredibly moist delicious cinnamon rolls! Thanks for the recipe!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent, made it using my kitchen aid was easy peasy. The only thing I did different was to use butter and not margarine, as we only ever buy butter. Also I used fresh yeast in place of dried yeast. I was skeptical about the dough because it looked like a hard block but I rolled it out, was not difficult at all. Spread the cinnamon mixture over it, rolled it up cut it, and placed it in a 9x13 inch pan as many others have suggested. When the 30 minute rising time was up, they totally filled the pan. They looked wonderful and were not too sticky icky gooey but a real cinnamon roll! I put a bit of cream cheese on top mixed with a bit of powdered sugar and vanilla sugar. Excellent! Will make these again and again. Thanks for sharing.

text:
Great recipe!  I made them tonight and they are delish!  I didn't use a muffin pan, but instead spaced them out on a 12x9, and made them a touch bigger and it yielded 9 buns, instead of 12.  They tasted fantastic with a little icing glaze (icing sugar, dash of vanilla and a couple tablespoons of cream).  The only change I would make is that when I make them again I'll use a smaller pan so they stick together and become a bit more gooey.  All in all, a wonderful recipe that I'll be using again!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-02-03T09:03:09.493
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3506657
Display Name:
MrsChmerkovskiy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

83

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are delicious and easy!  I made the recipe exactly as directed, with the exception of using butter in the dough instead of margarine and I left out the raisins. In the filling, I used 1/2 c. of I Can't Believe It's Not Butter, and it turned out absolutely fine.  Like some other posters, my dough never rose until I actually put the rolls into the oven, but that wasn't a big deal.  I baked these in a round cake pan, and there wasn't a ton of room for them to expand so they did look a little ugly when they came out of the oven.  They weren't stuck together though, and they looked absolutely fine after I slathered some glaze on them (just powdered sugar and milk). If I were making these to impress someone, or to take them to an event, I would use a 9x13. Making them as a Breakfast Night dinner for my family though, I'd use the cake pan again. It baked for about 30-35 minutes, and they were incredibly moist and gooey. Even the leftovers tasted just as good the next day. The only reason I didn't give it five stars was because the dough needed several more heaping teaspoons of flour added to it...it would have been way too sticky to roll otherwise.  I did everything in my KitchenAid...used the beater attachment first and then switched to the dough hook when it needed to be kneaded.  Once put together in the pan, I threw them in the fridge for a few hours before I baked them, and they were fine...just let them rest for a 1/2 hr. on the counter before they go in the oven.

text:
This was my first time making anything with yeast. They turned out perfect! I made them in a Pyrex 9x13 rectangular pan and used baking paper to line the pan. I also made a little extra of the cinnamon butter sugar mixture and spread on top right before baking.  I used a vanilla glaze recipe from the site. I made the batch and my boyfriend LOVED them! He said: "Babe, these are better than that place in the mall. I can't even remember the name." He was referring to Cinnabon! lol After they sat in a the cake container over night, I froze some in an airtight container. They still taste great 2 weeks later! I take one out of the freezer and by the time I get to work its defrosted enough to warm in the microwave to have with my coffee. Great recipe!

text:
These tasted delicious hot out of the oven.  I like the quick rise yeast method of adding the yeast with the dry ingredients. I thought the filling was perfect in taste, but it baked out onto my muffin tin and was a bit messy.  I think next time I will cut the rolls to fill about 2/3 of the tin and make a second pan if needed.  The way the middles pop up out of the rolls makes for a beautiful cinnamon roll.  I reheated them this morning and topped with butter, still yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ive made this recipe a few times: by hand, and by standup mixer. they are very tasty and rise well. i recommend using a standup mixer. your dough will be much more soft and fluffy. i put the yeast in 1/4 cup water and add 1/2 tsp sugar. let it sit until foamy for about 5-8 minutes. i add it in with the other wet ingredients. let the dough rise and need it.  add a little brown sugar and butter to a rectangular pan and bake.I also make a simple cream cheese frosting, and drizzle it over the  hot rolls. oh so delicious :) BIG HIT !

text:
Great easy recipe.  Dough comes out larger than the 13 X 9".  I doubled the sugar/cinnamon topping and added 1/2 c. white sugar in place of 1/2 c. brown sugar, added 1/2 tsp vanilla and 3 - 4 oz. cream cheese for filling.  I used 3/4 of mixture for filling and dribbled the remainder over the top before throwing in the oven.  Then I baked until golden brown.

text:
i made this so my husband could take it into work today for Mother's Day and all his staff loved it!! i followed the recipe to the T, but the only difference i did was instead of baking it right away, i cut it up into 12 equal pieces and placed them in the lightly greased muffin tins then i covered it up with plastic wrap and put it in the fridge overnight. before putting it in the 375 degree oven i let it sit out for about 30 minutes then baked it for 17 minutes and frosted them with the frosting from the "Savory Cinnamon Rolls" recipe. of course i will making this again, but only on special occasions..my husband and i can't eat all this by ourselves!!

text:
Tips for making it even better!--Roll the dough very thin, spread the filling out thinly, put it into a pan, and TURN THE PAN UPSIDE DOWN immediately after taking it out of the oven--that way the syrup will not all sink to the bottom.  I put mine in a 9x13 pan, which worked great!  I also made the cream cheese frosting from the "Clone of Cinnabon" recipe on this site.  All in all, five stars!  Excellent the first day, hot out of the oven, and excellent the second day, warmed up in the microwave!  Yum--I'll be making these again!

text:
I'm not a huge cinnabon fan but my husband is so I decided to try this recipe since the reviews were so good. I had NO previous experience using yeast and was pretty clueless about what I was about to attempt. My mom had some active dry yeast so that's what I used. I kept to the recipe except for using a 9x13 pan instead of the muffin pan. Since I never made anything with yeast before I wasn't sure how much it was supposed to rise before baking. It didn't seem to rise very much during the first "resting" period. They did spread out in the pan before baking so I felt better after that. I then made a simple powdered sugar/milk/vanilla extract icing because my husband likes things sweet although it wasn't overly sweet even with the extra icing. Everyone loved them. My husband ate 2. Would definitely make again.

text:
I mixed these up last night, and put them in a 9X13 pan in the fridge overnight.  This morning, I set them out for about an hour and baked for 25 minutes.  I frosted them with the cream cheese frosting suggested by MPCHARVAT.  DELICIOUS!!!  And very, very easy--the dough was the easiest yeast dough I've worked with.  Not too sticky, but still tender.  I will definitely use this in the future.  Thanks so much for a delicious Christmas breakfast recipe!*UPDATE* Tonight I made these as regular hot rolls--after the 10 minute rest, I shaped them into balls, baked for 20 minutes in a 9X13 pan and brushed with melted butter as soon as they came out of the oven.  Also delicious, and so easy!!!

text:
This was my first attempt at making my own cinnamon rolls, they turned out amazing! Very moist and delicious. As suggested before, I baked them in a baking dish, and i also added a little bit more melted butter, sugar and cinnamon on top before baking. For the frosting I used a recipe from this site that calls for 1 (3 oz) package of cream cheese, softened; 1/4 cup of butter, softened; 1 1/2 cups of confectioners sugar; 1/2 tsp vanilla extract; 1/8 tsp salt. Just beat all together and spread of warm rolls.

I'm eating this right now and had to write the review immediately. These are AMAZING. They took me just under 2 hours though (because I tend to not prep ahead of time), and they actually rose kind of funny in the oven, "tim burtony" describes them. I put them in a 9x13 pan and baked for 25 minutes, took them out when brown on top but still soft (not doughy) inside. I thought 1 tbsp cinnamon wouldn't be enough but it's perfect!! I topped them with cream cheese frosting someone else mentioned on here and they're delicious. I don't think I've ever had a cinnamon roll this good.

text:
Very good, sweet enough to not have a frosting on top but... what's a cinnamon roll without the cream cheese topping?!  Here's how I make my frosting:    2oz cream cheese 1.5t. vanilla 1/2t. salt 1T. white sugar  This recipe also really only took 90min.  The rolls didn't seem to rise as much as I hoped simply because they really weren't given much time to rise, but after baking them they had taken on the size I was looking for.  (Oh, and the raisins are a must!)

I was originally going to give this 3 stars because my dough was extremely sticky and uncooperative, even after adding another 1/2 cup of flour. However, the end result was amazingly good! But I used active dry yeast instead of instant, so it took longer than the 90 minutes. I also added some of the recommended cream cheese frosting and they were to die for. I actually think I like them more than cinnabon... and I LOVE cinnabon.  EDIT: I made these again for a bake sale (still with active dry yeast not instant) and this time my dough was very easy to handle and they came out great.

userID:
2467488
Display Name:
Wildflower86

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/109.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are awesome cinnamon rolls! Like other reviewers, I found the dough to be very sticky, and ended up adding an extra 1/2 cup of flour in the mixing bowl, plus an additional 2 tbsps while kneading. Fortunately, the additional flour didn't seem to affect the finished product which had a soft, not-"bready", texture. The type of yeast I used was one package of Fleischmann's Rapid Rise Yeast. I took other reviewer's suggestions and increased the "filling" ingredients as follows: butter to 3/4 cup, brown sugar to 1 1/4 cup, and cinnamon to 1 1/2 tbsps. (Plus I sprinkled with the suggested 1/2 cup raisins). After rolling up the dough, I sliced it into 18 slices which I placed side-by-side in a 9 X 13 greased pan. Baked for 15 minutes, and they came out beautifully. They were sweet enough (with the "filling" changes) that they didn't need a glaze. However, next time ---in order to cut back on calories-- I'll try the original filling and after baking, will drizzle a light powdered-sugar glaze over top. This will be the cinnamon roll recipe I use from now on.

text:
I was so impressed with this recipe, that this is my first written review.  I've had my share of making cinnamon rolls from different recipes and almost all of them would never turn out right.  But this recipe came out perfect-wow!  I don't know what I did right, but I did tweak the recipe as I try to use whole wheat flour in my baking.  I used 2 cups of white flour, 1 cup whole wheat flour, and left out the extra 1/4 cup.  I used 3/4 cup of rice milk since I have a daughter who is allergic to milk, and used 2 eggs since the wheat flour absorbs so much liquid.  I also added about 1/2 tsp more of yeast.  It rose great and turned out just like the picture!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
FABULOUS!!! No joke! I can't begin to tell you how many times I have tried recipes only to be horribly disappointed in the final product. This recipe is absolutely wonderful. I had tried several other cinnamon roll recipes and they just didn't make the cut. I added a few finely crushed walnuts along with the raisins. I used a simple icing (even though the buttery rich gooyness made the rolls sweet enough to eat alone). Rather than baking them in muffin pan I placed them in a 10inch round cake pan and let them rise in the pan. Watch your baking time so they don't overbake. I will definitely make these again, and again!

This was my first time making cinnamon rolls.  My 10 year old daughter, her friend, and I made a batch this mornings.  The girls said it was the best they ever had in their lives.  It was super easy to make.  I did let it rise twice, 1st time after kneading and the second time after cutting the rolls out with dental floss.  I used a basic glaze of 1/4 c butter, 3 T fat free milk, 1 T vanilla, and 2 c powdered sugar.  It definitely gets you on a sugar high!!!

Wow! Simply amazing! They were very tender and delicious, the perfect combination of flavours. The only changes I made was that I added some cinnamon to the dough itself, I let them rise for about an hour before baking, and I baked them in a cake pan. I only baked them for 17 minutes, and they were perfect! I also mixed some brown sugar and milk together and poured it over the buns right before baking. It made them nice and gooey, and they didn't dry out at all! I will definitely make this recipe again. Over and over again! Thanks!

None
text:
My kids helped make these for breakfast, and they were delicious! Ours took a little longer than 90 minutes, but that was because I didn't have any instant yeast. I used dry active instead, mixed it in 1/2 cup water, let it foam for about 10 minutes, and then added it to the rest of the ingredients. After letting the dough rise about an hour, we prepared the cinnamon rolls as directed and placed them in a 9x13 pan. The second rise took about 40 minutes. My kids were thrilled to see the rolls puffed up to fill the whole pan! We baked according to directions & frosted with cream cheese icing. We will be making these again and again. Thanks!

I could not believe the success I had in making these! I wasn't sure if I had to proof the yeast first, but I just added it in the mixture dry and they came out fine. Only problem was that the dough didnt double as quickly as it was supposed to, but I had time. I think I'll substitute coconut milk and add semi-sweet chocolate chips and coconut flakes the next time I make these. Be careful with these when in the oven. I wanted to check them after 25 mins and didn't get to them until after 28 mins, and that was all it took to overcook 'em. THey were still great, just a tad browner.

Good and pretty easy, does take longer than 90 minutes, more like 2 hours, still, if you do not have a bread machine this is perfect. I followed the directions exactly, except I added a cream cheese frosting. The frosting is 4 oz. of cream cheese, 1/4 cup of softened butter, 2 cups of powdered sugar, 1/2 tsp. of vanilla, pinch of salt, 1-2 tablespoons of milk depending on desired consistency.

text:
Excellent recipe, of many that I tried in my quest to make a cinnamon roll! I replaced 2 c. of flour with golden buffalo whole wheat flour and they came out amazing, I just had to increase the rise time for the yeast to act against the heavier flour.
I was also able to make these vegan without a hitch. I used Earthbalance vegan buttery sticks, and Tofutti vegan "cream cheese." I've made them both vegan and with "the real thing"...butter, eggs, all that good stuff. I prefer the real thing, but the vegan ones are quite popular with the alternative croud here. Thank you for sharing!

These werewonderful! I followed the recipe as stated, but then put them in 2 round cake pans. I refridgerated them overnight and put 1 pan out early the next morning to come to room temp. and rise. They cooked up beautifully and the guests I had over for coffee LOVED them. I did use cream cheese frosting, but not too much, they are sweet and yummy alone! I used the other pan the next day - 2 days of cinnamon rolls! WHAT COULD BE BETTER? The dough was fantastically easy to work with (I used my KithenAid mixer to knead it) and something I will definitely make again. Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
I've tried a few other cinnamon roll recipes, which were much more difficult and time consuming than these, but these were by far the BEST!! This is a simple recipe that produces an outstanding cinnamon roll. Add the frosting, 1 1/2 cups powdered sugar, 1/2 cup softened margarine, 1/2 tsp vanilla, and 1/8 tsp salt...and it's to die for. I don't have cream cheese but the frosting is good without it. These don't last an hour in my house. I do like to bake 9 of them in a lightly greased round pan and the other 3 in the muffin pans. I've already given this recipe to my sister...who loved them...and my mother...who also loved them. Thanks for the recipe, Debbie. It's a keeper for me.

text:
Our family loved these and I have to say I used 2 1/4 tsp active dry yeast in place of the instant yeast packet and that seemed to do the trick thankfully.
I was skeptical but I'm glad I did it anyway. I also used my kitchenaid mixer which was a nice help.  Afer making these last night I decided to only bake 4 of them to see how they'd come out (because of the yeast alteration) they spread apart too much and didn't hold together in shape well but the others I left in the freezer overnight in the pan covered in plastic wrap and pulled out and put directly in the oven for 30 minutes and they came out perfect.  I let the rest as someone else suggested for a few minutes to cool/firm up.  They were absolutely great and perfect in flavor.  Thanks so much for an excellent/easy recipe.  I would imagine that pecans would be great on these.

text:
Cinnamon Rolls and I forgot the cinnamon! It was still very good. Next, time I won't make the raisins optional- I think their needed. I put the cinn. rolls in the oven to rise, by turning the oven onto low and once it "beeped" or reached the temp, I turned the oven off. There is to much margarine for the mixture, it bubbled over and smoked up the house. I would cut it down to 1/4 cup and keep the brown sugar the same. These seem like their only good when they are warm, we will see. I used a old high school home ec recipe (8 oz cream cheese, 1 cup powdered sugar, 2 tsp lemon juice and 1 T milk) for cream cheese frosting and it was good. This time I would give it only 3 +, but I forgot the cinn. And with adding raisins and decreasing the butter, I think I would give it a 5. So I will give it a 4 to be fair. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Over the months I've made some minor changes to these:  a quarter cup more flour so the dought is still soft but easier to handle, milk instead of water (personal preference, I find that milk makes bread dry out quicker), butter (instead of margarine) in the filling reduced to a quarter cup (takes a bit more time to spread).  The rolls rise up nicely.  I am far too lazy to prepare muffin tins so usually make these in a parchment-lined cake pan.

AWESOME recipe! I TRIPLED the recipe, added chopped walnuts, replaced the raisins for dried cranberries (all I had at the time) and viola! TASTY and MOIST! Everyone at church LOVED THEM!!! I made a cream cheese, butter, vanilla, confectioners sugar and salt (mix all together) frosting for the top. THANK YOU for this E-Z and very good recipe! I do agree that 20 minutes is TOO LONG to bake them. 15-16 minutes in a perfectly calibrated oven is definitely enough time. Just keep an eye on them...when lightly golden brown...THEY ARE DONE! :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/22456.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe for a girl in a hurry. I have used this dough with the caramel sauce I found in another recipe on this  site -- 1/2 c butter/margarine, 1/2 c vanilla ice cream, 1/2 c brown sugar brought to a boil over medium heat and boiled 5 mins. Pour into bottom of greased 9x13 baking dish and allow to cool while preparing cinnamon rolls. Place rolls in dish to rise and bake. I find it useful to bake the rolls covered in foil for 15 mins or so and then uncover the remaining time. This allows the rolls to be cooked through while preventing overbrowning. The caramel sauce is really what makes the recipe. I've received nothing but compliments and requests that I make more.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a terrific recipe.  I was looking for a perfect cinnamon roll recipe and this was it.  I made this for my family this morning.  I used unsalted butter instead of margarine in the dough and salted butter in the filling instead of margarine.  I didn't add extra flour and just kneaded the good and sticky dough between both hands.  More flour would have made this dough tough and dry.  I baked these in a deep baking dish, as I would any prepackaged frozen roll.  Didn't have any problems with the filling oozing outside of the dish.  I did top with a thin icing of cream cheese, milk, vanilla and powdered sugar.  I will make this one again and again.  YUM

userID:
26650086
Display Name:
Kaley Bird's Cabin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
71
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed making this recipe. I would recommend: if you prefer fuller, puffier cinnamon rolls, let the dough proof longer until it has doubled in size, about twice the amount of time said in the recipe. This is what I did, and the cinnamon rolls came out fabulous, like gourmet quality. When I was coating the inside of the dough with the cinnamon mix, I actually had really soft butter (I softened in the microwave) which made the mix very wet. This actually worked in my favor. Yes, the dough had become very messy when rolling and cutting, but it added so much flavor to the finished product. I didn't put these in muffin tins either; I hand-rolled each one due to the messy cinnamon mix and put them on parchment lined baking sheets, spread far enough apart so they wouldn't stick together. For glaze, I just had 1 part milk to 3-4 parts powdered sugar for a thick glaze. I didn't measure, just had a larger amount of powdered sugar to milk. I drizzled it on top of the cooled cinnamon rolls and it made a huge difference in the appearance. I had a lot of people tell me these cinnamon rolls were so amazing, they never made it home!
Review:

I follow this recipe nearly to a T. (I use butter instead of margarine).  These have the taste and texture of what I want in a cinnamon roll.  Perfect sweetness.  Great tender texture.   Super easy and very quick too.  I have even stopped at step 4 and put them in the fridge overnight so that I could have fresh cinnamon rolls with coffee in the morning.  I just take them out of the fridge and allow an hour to rise.  They are always done exactly at 30 minutes in the oven.  I love how reliable this recipe is.  Itâs my go-to cinnamon roll recipe.  These work well with cream cheese frosting too.  Sometimes I put cream cheese frosting on half and the traditional butter, milk, powdered sugar frosting on the other half.

userID:
23753760
Display Name:
Klei Custodio
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6717185.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Turned out very soft on the inside! I used active dry yeast so I made it a little different. First, in a Pyrex measuring cup I mixed the milk, egg, water, sugar and butter. I melted the butter in the microwave and made sure that the temperature was around 100-110F. I transferred it to a mixing bowl and it lost heat so I had to reheat some of the mixture and mixed that back in. Next time I will heat the mixture to 120F so when I transfer it, itâll be perfect for the yeast. I sprinkled the yeast on top of the mixture, mixed it, and let it proof in the oven with the lamp on for about 10 minutes. I sifted in the flour and salt and had my Kitchenaid with the dough hook knead the dough until smooth. After, I took it out and put the dough in the oven with the lamp on, towel over the bowl, and let it rise for around 45min-1hr or until double the size. You can make the filling while it rises. I sprinkled flour on the surface before rolling out the dough (donât roll it out too thin). After, I spread on the filling to the very ends of the dough. I rolled it tightly. This step is very important for your dough to keep its swirl. Use string to cut the dough. Placed them in my buttered glass containers, then they rose for 45 minutes in the oven with a towel over and the lamp on again. The oven preheated to 350 while it rose and I put it in for about 30 minutes. Next time I will lower the heat as the middle cooked slower and so there will be less crunch on the outside.

text:
I have made these *numerous* times.  We love them.  I have given them as gifts many times.  I have always been given rave reviews when I take them anywhere.  One friend I gave them to always gives me back the pan and asks for it to be refilled! I make the cream cheese frosting that one reviewer mentioned (first review on "most helpful").  I have never had a problem, they have always been beautiful.  I put the yeast in with the dry ingredients, I do not proof it.  The only thing I do differently is I use butter, not margarine. These are amazing and I'm addicted to making them! They have made me famous among my peers LOL! I would also add that buying quality ingredients is helpful.  Don't skimp on the brand of butter or yeast.  When I make the cream cheese frosting, I use Kelly Gold Irish Butter.  Sure, those ingredients are more expensive, but they are worth it for a better outcome!

text:
Most delicious and easiest cinnamon rolls I've ever made!! My toddler asked for cinnamon rolls out of no where this morning so I was trying to find a recipe that didn't require a bunch of prep or a trip to the store and I'll honestly never use a different recipe now. I DID add 1t of vanilla to the filing, and I kept adding cinnamon until I could actually taste it. I opted for a baking dish instead of muffin tin and I have no regrets there. After greasing the dish I smeared a layer of the filling in the bottom like you do with lasagna, and after placing the cut rolls in it I put more filling on top of them before covering it to let them rise. I baked them in the oven uncovered for 20 minutes and they came out PERFECT!! I just topped them with a basic powdered sugar & milk glaze and served them warm. They are now a family breakfast staple in my house

country:
None
text:
These delicious cinnamon rolls have become a regular weekend breakfast treat at our house.  In terms of ingredients I follow the recipe exactly, though in terms of technique I follow a few suggestions from other reviews that I think are worthwhile: 1) I do about 30 minutes in a warm place for both rises, not just the second one.  This leads to softer, fluffier rolls.  If Iâm pressed for time, I use the microwave rise method, which cuts the time of both rises about in half.  2) Instead of mixing all the filling ingredients together, I melt the butter and brush it over the dough, then sprinkle the brown sugar, cinnamon, and raisins.  I find this results in a more even spread of the filling.  3) I use dental floss to cut the rolls.  4) I cut them into about 15 rolls, and bake them together in a greased 9x12 pan.  For my oven, the baking time is still about 20 minutes as suggested in the recipe.  5) I let them cool then frost the whole lot with cream cheese frosting.  You donât technically have to let them cool before doing this if you want them really warm and gooey, but it makes for a much nicer presentation (great for potlucks!), and I actually prefer eating them cooled.

text:
These were really good when I made them. I did make the following adjustments:

- Instead of mixing the yeast with the dry ingredients, as suggested in the recipe, I mixed it with the water and half the sugar, leaving the rest of the sugar with the dry ingredients

- I kneaded the dough until you could stretch it to the point where you could see light through it

- I proved it for an hour after kneading, and 45 minutes once I shaped them, before baking

I hope my suggestions are useful!

Turned out Yummy!!  First I have to admit when it comes to baking and using yeast, for some reason it usually doesnât turn out for me. But with this recipe I made 4 different batches for my oldest granddaughters end of senior year breakfast at sunrise. 2 out of the 4 seemed to rise properly and the other 2 only a little.  I went ahead and baked anyway and even though they were smaller, the flavor was the same.  The kids loved them.  Will continue to make them and learn how to get dough to rise properly.  But itâs good to know that if they donât rise all the way, they are still very good and will not have a problem getting eaten.

text:
Before I make any recipes from ALLRECIPES I read the reviews and break them down to fit my needs. The reviews for these cinnamon rolls had many concerns about sticking to the pan & overflow in the oven. To prevent the problem I did the following:  I used a 9x13 âhigh edgeâ cake baking pan. I sprayed it with cooking spray then put parchment paper in the bottom. Then sprayed the parchment paper. ....I did Not have any problems with overflow or Cinnamon Rolls sticking. I even cooled them in the pan. And clean up was very easy.                                                       Added note: This is an excellent recipe!                                                      I did make them the night before then set them out in the morning about an hour before putting them in the oven. As suggested from one person to add 2T of flour to the filling, I wanted to do that but forgot. So while sitting out before cooking some filling leaked out looking a bit runny. This was not a problem but the flour could have helped.

text:
Great recipe, got amazing cinnamon rolls. However I also got a small fire in my oven because I didn't put a cookie sheet under the muffin tin. The syrup fell and got on fire. We got rid of the fire quickly but please put a under your muffin tin to catch the syrup and check the oven  from time to time. Someone else suggested this as well.

My dough became too gooey by the way, so what  I did was spread the dough in a rectangle, spread the cinnamon butter and then refrigerate for some time. Then I was able to roll it up way better.

text:
Great recipe! Easy to follow. I did not have Instant Yeast, so I used Active Dry yeast, and they did just fine. The dough did not rise much, and I was worried they would stay flat because of the yeast, but in the oven they poofed out nicely! I did as other reviewers and baked in a 9x9 baking dish rather than muffin tins (easier to clean!)   So delicious!  Easy to throw together a glaze for the top -- milk and powdered sugar, or a cream cheese frosting, depending on what's around.

I was looking for a recipe that didnât take 3 hours to make. These werenât too time consuming if you start early enough for your family to enjoy for breakfast before lunch if you had to wait. I made 6 big cinnamon rolls in a circular metal pan. Needed to bake about 25 mins. I made cinnamon roll icing without cream cheese and couldnât find any from allrecipes so I used a recipe the the spruce.com, these were delicious, not nutritious as I say about baked goods that taste amazing but arenât the best for the waste line

text:
4 16 17 ... Happy Easter! ... http://allrecipes.com/recipe/17006/ninety-minute-cinnamon-rolls/ ... 'Not first time using yeast, but it's been quite a while; first time yeast cinnamon rolls.  This is a good recipe, but it didn't knock my socks off.  I had to add more flour, more than expected & still not enough so I had a stickiness problem.  The cinnamon filling was either too soft or too much; maybe both.  It was messy.  I put blinders on & just kept going.  I attempted to cut in two then each half three times for twelve.  The filling slopped the dough so much, I just cut three of each half - so six very large rolls.  I literally scooped them up with help from a spatula & placed on a jellyroll pan & baked about 20 minutes.  They filled the pan & taste good, but not so pretty.  'Made 'em to eat, not look at anyway so "we good"!  Sum up:  The dough is soft & good.  I may find another dough recipe I like better, but this one's good; the filling, I'll keep looking; but it is good, too.  Thanks for sharing with us!

text:
Not too hard and my 12 year old was able to help quite a bit. These don't take too long, and yet they rise pretty well. Ours were quite tall and didn't fit well into a 12 cup muffin pan, so I would recommend slicing them a bit thinner and make more like 14 or so. The cinnamon mixture oozed out and dripped onto the bottom of the oven, so it would be helpful to place the muffin pan onto a baking tray first. Pretty tasty and a bit crispy. We added nuts as well.

text:
This really is a simple and delicious recipe. I did not make them in muffin tins because that didn't really make sense to me, so I made them in a standard 9x13 baking dish. Additionally, the recipe calls for the use of softened margarine for the filling, but I found the consistency too soft making it hard to hold together while I was rolling it up and cutting. The second  time I made these I used slightly softened stick butter instead and it mde the roll and cut much easier. All in all the dough is rich and delicious and the recipe is easy

text:
Delicious. Followed the recipe as written except for the following changes:
I used regular yeast that I let bloom in the 1/4 cup of warm water for 10 minutes. Milk was warmed in microwave. Added both raisins and walnuts. Took a little longer to rise. Baked in 9 X 13 pan using parchment paper (as suggested by other commenters) and turned out onto another piece of parchment when done. My second attempt at a yeast raised dough and both were successful. Possibly a little too sweet with the 1 cup of brown sugar - I used demerara so maybe that made a difference - but I will definitely make again.

text:
Love at 375ÂºF! Excellent recipe! 
The only unique touches I added are:
1/2 tsp nutmeg & pinch of cardamom in the dough.
I chose to bake in a 12"x9" pan - opting out of the muffin pan method, although that sounds interesting.
Since the recipe gives no frosting, I chose a cream cheese frosting. (4oz cream cheese, 1/4 c butter, 1/2 tsp vanilla & 1 c powdered sugar)
Omitted the raisins and added pecans in their place. 

The dough was splendidly easy to make & directions a breeze to follow. Since these ones are almost gone already, I am certain to be making them again very soon!

text:
I chose this recipe because it doesn't require a bread machine as most recipes seem to need.  I'm a novice when it comes to bread making and was afraid to try and convert the instructions. I made the rolls the night before and put them in a 9x13 pan. Brought them to room temp to rise a bit more before baking on Christmas morning. They rose beautifully, the rolls were light and fluffy. I gave it four stars because the filling was a bit dry. Next time I will increase the amount of butter to 3/4 cup and perhaps double the filling recipe so I can put some in the bottom of the pan. We wished they were a bit 'gooeyer', but still they were a success.

Followed suggestions by others. Made the rolls the night before and refridgerated them overnight. Allowed time to rise in the morning. 6322251
Display Name:
Beth

city:

region:
None
country:

text:
I am generally not a baker and if I am, I love my bread machine.  This was my first attempt with a yeast dough by "hand".  And by that I mean, my Kitchen Aid got a workout ;-)  I mixed the yeast with the dry ingredients in the mixer bowl.  I used a 2 cp Pyrex to heat the milk in the microwave about 2 minutes.  To that I added cold butter and warm water.  I beat my egg separately then tempered with some of the milk mix, keeping an eye on the temp.  Right around 122* I added that to the flour/yeast mix and let it go.  I ended up needing about 1/2 cp extra flour to make it form (don't panic with this, it all depends on your house, the weather, the flour, etc)  I cut down my brown sugar to about 3/4 cp, mixed it with 1/4 cp melted butter and spread it on the dough about 1/2 inch from the edges.  I added 1/4 chopped pecans and rolled it.  I purposely cut it into 6 rounds, put it in a 9x13 glass Pyrex (greased with butter) and let it sit on top of my fridge (the warmest spot in my house when the oven is off) while I did other things.  The rolls did not rise UP, but out, which I fully expected.  Popped 'em in the oven for 20 minutes after brushing with a little melted butter and ta-da!  Yes, I realize by the time it was all said and done I probably used a full stick of butter, but it is SO worth it.  But I suppose if you're looking for 'diet' recipes, you're not making cinnamon rolls ;-)  I also glazed with some powdered sugar, vanilla and milk.  Cinnamon rolls are the only thing I
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

country:
None
text:
this recipe was perfect! I did a couple things differently and they were still amazing. I was out if milk so I used water and I only had traditional yeast not quick rise yeast. I combined my yeast, the white sugar and 3/4 cup of warm water and let sit until frothy to activate the yeast. I melted butter rather than matgarine and stirred it with the 1/4 cup of water beat an egg into it. Then combined all wet ingredients and poured over the flour. I used a stand mixer to knead the dough which was a huge time saver! I used the tip from other reviews to bake in a  pan rather than muffin tins and did not regret it! just make sure to us a 9x12 pan with a baking sheet under it! I mixed extra butter sugar and cinnamon to top the rolls with too :) I will definitely make these again.

city:

country:
None
text:
Excellent rolls--i will definitely make these again. My family and I liked them a lot. I left out the stick of butter called for in between layers, just spreading the rectangle of dough with cinnamon sugar and raisins and pressing them in with a rolling pin before rolling up the dough. This resulted in much less messy rolls that still tasted plenty rich and buttery.
    I also left off the icing, and we didn't miss it.
    To boost nutrition a bit (we have a growing son who is vegetarian and a selective eater) I added 1/4-1/2c instant dry milk, 1/4c ground flax seed, and 1/4c whey protein powder. All were healthful, unobtrusive additions.

None
text:
I make these rolls regularly for my family. The only way I vary from the recipe is that I bake them in a 9x13 pan instead of muffin tins and I drizzle cream cheese frosting over them. They are delicious, quick and easy. Also, they freeze really well: instead of placing them in the pan to rise, place them on a cookie sheet and freeze. Pop them in a ziplock back and pull some out the night before baking to thaw and rise in the baking pan. Bake as directed. Delicious!

text:
IT WAS AWESOME! My family really liked it and it was rich and flavorful. Using brown sugar in the filling was a great idea. I let it ferment/rise for a bit longer (around 40 minutes) and I think that helped contribute to the amazing fluffiness of the rolls. Also, seeing other people's comments I baked the rolls in a flat dish to account for their explosive growth. Definitely our new family recipe for comfort sweets!

text:
Great and so much faster and easier than with a bread maker, if you can believe it! I added about 1/2 c. nuts to the filling and made up a big bowl of icing (powdered sugar, milk, lemon juice) and slathered the rolls with it when they came out of the oven. Oh, and I didn't use muffin cups but crammed 'em into a baking dish - it took about 3 minutes longer to bake this way, but I prefer the pull-apart kind!

Oh I love these cinnamon rolls! This was my first attempt at cinnamon rolls and wow! They were VERY easy and couldn't have been more delicious! I let them rest about 20 minutes instead of 10 because I got busy but that didn't affect the form or taste. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect, yummy, easy. A breeze w a Kitchenaid. This is my official recipe now. Updating my previous review: first time I made these I chilled overnight and baked them straight to the oven- there was very little "goo" that seeped out the bottom. Today, I did it overnight but let the rolls warm on the counter. This time, a lot of filling oozed out and created a sticky Carmely bottom & had to e flipped into a baking sheet. This wasn't a bad thing- my oldest son preferred the sticky but I did not. So, same concept as refrigerating cookie dough- the filling stays firmer with less spread if the dough is chilled. Delicious either way!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3046257.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious recipe even without anything added or changed! I am not very skilled at all, so this recipe took me much more than 90 minutes, but the end result was amazing! Just to experiment with icing, I looked over some recipes, but they all seemed to make way too much icing. I threw together a spoonful of cream cheese, a spoonful of powdered sugar (not sifted), a few small shavings of butter (not softened), and poured a little bit of vanilla. I added a little more powdered sugar later for taste and texture. Mixed together for about five minutes to really get those powdered sugar and butter chunks out. I ended up with the perfect amount (maybe a tablespoon or two of icing) and the texture was how I wanted, sticky but very consistent. Good luck!

text:
I thought this recipe was easy and didn't take a lot of time! Its so nice not having to wait for them to rise 2x, 1 hour each like most bread recipes. This dough is easy to make with a stand mixer. I used a 9x13 pan instead of a muffin pan and they came out nicely. Quite honestly, I'm not sure why you would use a muffin pan for these. I made these for easter and everyone really enjoyed them! Next time I will bake these for a little less than 20 minutes because mine came out a little too brown (the tops were hard and crispy). But that  is probably the fault of my oven. This recipe is definitely a keeper! Now I will make these more often now that I know it doesn't take a long time to make.

I have used  All Recipes for many years now.  This is the first review I've left.  I wouldn't classify myself as a cinnamon roll lover... But these  Cinnamon Rolls are amazing. text:
Delicious! The recipe itself is a very good cinnamon roll dough to be creative with, today I had 3/4c of heavy cream to use up so I used that instead of milk and omitted the egg, I also used white whole wheat flour, a spreadable butter instead of margarine, let the dough rise until double, rolled it out, spread a thin layer of Nutella, a sprinkle of cinnamon sugar, an extra sprinkle of just cinnamon, used floss to cut into rolls, put them in a buttered square baking dish, let them rise, baked 375 for 20 minutes( first time I made this I spread the dough with butter & cinnamon sugar & sliced almonds) both times the rolls turned out great

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Love this recipe!  I tweaked it a little by warming the milk in microwave, then adding butter to warm milk. I beat two eggs and used the warm milk to temper the eggs, then combined together with a teaspoon of vanilla for a richer dough. I increased the sugar to 1/2 cup  and  increased granulated yeast to 1 tablespoon.  I baked them at 375 for 20 min in a 9x13 quarter sheet pan and flipped it over onto another sheet pan covered with parchment then drizzled with powdered sugar glaze. Been making these at least once a month and holiday mornings for a year now and my family loves them. Warm,rich and gooey. TERRIFIC!

text:
Excellent recipe. I followed everything as followed, but substituted equal parts butter for margarine (as I do not use it). I baked them in a 9x 13" pyrex, yielding about 12 rolls. Once baked I just flip the rolls onto a baking sheet. I finished it with a vanilla cream cheese frosting. Do not let the relatively short "90" minutes be a turn off, these are as the best I have made and possibly the best I have ever had. Try them for yourself and see, you will not be disappointed.

text:
Great recipe. I don't advocate using a muffin tin, though, because I think the rolls get a little dried out. I like the rolls to touch each other so the sides stay soft.
I use my Kitchenaid mixer/dough hook to knead the dough, and that made the process very, very easy.

text:
Here is what I did to make it faster. Heat up 3/4 of the milk then use the other fourth to cool it to lukewarm. Melt margarine then brush on dough followed by sprinkling brown sugar and cinnamon. It's easier and faster than trying to spread a thick filling over the dough.  Also if you don't have brown sugar you can use white sugar mixed with a little bit of molasses. If you want to be exact with that substitution you can find a recipe for that on the internet.

I made these yesterday and they were delicious. I opted to melt some butter and spread it directly onto the rolled out dough with a brush and apply the brown sugar and cinnamon combination out by hand. (It's not as dense and I felt like the distribution was a lot more even this way.) I also didn't use a muffin tin and put them into a deep dish baking tray and they came out heavenly. I made a quick frosting out of cream cheese, icing sugar, milk and vanilla. They went fast in my house!

city:

region:

country:

text:
This was my first time making cinnamon rolls and they turned out great! I'm so happy I found this recipe, it was a quick and easy process. I had extra time so I mixed the yeast with the milk and butter then added it to the flour mixture after letting it develop for 15 min.The dough itself is delicious , I had leftover dough and decided to form them into buns and throw them in the oven as well.Just brush it with an egg yolk and you get beautiful golden brown and glossy bread buns.Since I had only a bit of butter left I decided to fill part of the dough with the cinnamon mixture and the other half with a chocolate cinnamon pecan concoction containing semi sweet chocolate,condensed milk,cinnamon and chopped pecans. I let in set in the fridge before spreading onto the dough.Soo good!! This recipe will definitely be my go to when my family and I are in the mood for some cinnamon rolls!

text:
This recipe makes for extra special Saturday morning brunches!! The only changes are that I use real unsalted butter and a drop of vanilla in the dough. While still hot from the oven, I drizzle with a light glaze -- mix 1/2 cup 10x sugar, drop of vanilla, pinch of cinnamon and enough milk to thicken it (2 tsp - 1/2 TBS).

text:
I've already made this for an N number of times. I tried the original recipe first before making substitutions so I could compare. The original recipe is already good as is. Today I ran out of milk, so I used full cream milk powder and some hot water; I did increase the milk in the recipe  to 1 cup though (so I don't have to scale down to 3/4 cup). I also tried subbing oil for the butter in the dough (not doing it again unless I run out of butter or margarine). I would change nothing in this recipe... well, except for the amount of milk.

These were excellent. I used active dry yeast though and followed someone's recommendation to mix it with lukewarm water. I did that for 10 minutes and then added it to the flour and added all the other stuff ... egg, milk, margarine. I also topped it with icing right after removing them from the oven (1.5 cups icing sugar, 1/4 cup butter, 1 tbsp or so of milk, 1 tsp vanilla).

text:
I am giving this one five stars because the dough and filling are perfect.  The method of baking is not.  I tried baking them both in a 13x9 dish and in the muffin tins, as the recipe suggests.  The ones I baked in the dish came out gooey and moist.  They only lasted two days.  The ones in the muffin tins came out very dry, and it was a struggle to get my family to eat them.  Plus, the filling overflowed from the muffin tin and is even now stuck to the bottom of my oven.  It smokes every time I preheat it.

text:
Amazing cinnamon buns! Made all the changes suggested in the reviews. Heated the 1/4C water till lukewarm (110-115F) then added the yeast and made it sit for 10 mins. I also baked in an 11"x 8" pan which was lined with parchment paper. About 5 minutes before they were done, I took a pastry brush and spread the cinnamon sugar butter mix on top of the buns to make them even more moist! Soooooo good! Thank you GOOFYDEBBIE!!

Display Name:
aktifistri

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/904738.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe this afternoon for after dinner dessert - as a company to watch winter olympics with hubby. Turned out it was a big success (to me as a very beginner). He was loving it :D Got a big compliment as well (which is not easy to get from him!), saying like "wow,finally my wife makes this after 7 years of marriage..it's better than cinnabon!" lol.. not sure if he was exaggerating :p I only care that he loves it as a special treat. He even said, "you can also sell this, hun!". Unexpected to hear from him. :D

Enough of the bragging, lol.. anyway, I made some modification. I put glaze (not on this recipe) which is from; confectioners sugar, milk, vanilla essence, and...a little mixture of water and cornstarch to thicken the glaze since I don't have cream today. Turned out pretty good!

The dough, I noticed the video version calls for 'active dry yeast', while the written version calls for 'instant dry yeast'. I didn't have 'active yeast' so I used 'instant' one instead. Turns out well - I've no complain about the dough. Rising perfectly. I tasted a bit stronger yeast taste, but not annoying. Just tasted like how bread is.

The butter for filling, instead of softening it, I melted it then mix it with the mix of brown sugar and lots of cinnamon (I put extra cinnamon cos hubby loves it). Turned out, it was a bit too watery but I feel it's easier to spread on the dough. But I think I'll prefer the 'soften the butter' way for next time so it won't give wet final result.

text:
I did as recipe stated except I used butter instead of margarine and luckily did not use muffin tins. I just baked in a baking sheet with high sides. 
The flavor ended up being good, my kids loved it. But the dough was VERY sticky! It ended up only making 8 decent size rolls. I think next time I will use more butter and spread on the dough then sprinkle the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture on it seperately. Then after its rolled up brush with more butter and brown sugar/cinnamon mixture on the outside the dough just seemed bland on the bare parts. I fixed that with some cream cheese frosting though.

text:
WOW!! I made these for Christmas morning and they were a HUGE hit! I made 2 batches and since my husband is a diabetic I used Splenda in one batch and Lite brown sugar for the cinnamon mixture, and the other batch was as the recipe is written. Both batches came out tasting wonderfully delicious! I surprised my husband with them and he was more than excited to try them! The cinnamon rolls turned out so light and do in fact taste like the ones you can purchase in the mall as one of the other reviewers stated, except I think these are better! They are simple to male and the aroma from the oven is pure heaven. Do make sure you have something in the oven to catch the oozey goodness. Not much, but some! Thanks for sharing this recipe. I will definitely be baking them again soon!

This turned out beautifully, but I did slightly change it. The quantities are all the same, except I made 1.5x of the filling. Also I warmed up the water and added 1Tbs of the sugar, and let the yeast bloom for 10 minutes. Also I let it rise for 30 minutes near the oven vent before rolling it out.

None
text:
Just pulled these out of the oven and OMW! Heavenly! I almost didn't make them because I saw the 1 star reviews, but I don't know what is wrong with those people! I have made many different Cinnamon Roll recipes, but none of them had the perfect texture/flavor I craved. THESE HIT IT PERFECTLY! They don't even need icing - they are THAT yummy. My husband said they were the best I've ever made, and we both agree that they are way better than Cindy's in the mall (Those never taste as good as they smell).  I followed the recipe exactly.  Remember, depending on where you live and the weather on the day you bake, you may need more or less flour.  The weather today was very mild and dry here, and I used the exact amount of flour called for. I baked them in a 9x13 glass pan, on top of a jelly pan in case of overflow (none actually occurred,) for 30 min. Watch the video.

text:
My first time making cinnamon rolls and I was very impressed with the results.  The only mistake I made was that I used active dry yeast and I just threw it in with the flour instead of letting it rise in warm water. After doing a "google" search to fix this mistake, I just let it rise an extra half hour and it was fine. I looked at the other reviews for helpful hints and I baked it in a 9 x 13 glass dish and brush it with melted margarine.  I also used my stand mixer for kneading the dough which was a great help.

I made this with my 6-year-old, and we made it with my lactose intolerant son in my mind specifically. To make it non dairy, I subbed melted  coconut oil for the butter and used almond milk instead of cow's milk. I didn't have brown sugar, so I mixed some molasses into regular sugar. We baked it in a 9x13 pan, and it turned out great. We sprinkled a touch of powdered sugar over the top and served it up!

text:
5 stars all the way!  Just made a pan of these rolls and they live up to the hype.  Recipe is spot on. Dough was velvety and easy to work with. Filling to dough ratio was perfect.

Using a baking pan gave them soft edges. The muffin tin gave them baked edges all around, but they rose to a gorgeous spiral peak.  I'll be baking them both ways. Topped them with a little smear of simple cream cheese icing.  Can't wait to share these with coworkers at my elementary school. Teachers love good food!

None
text:
The recipe is perfect, I've made this recipe a bunch of times and everyone loves it every time. I've also been trying to find the right combination. I finally decided that it's best when you use a 12x9 pan. If you do decide to use muffin tins, which are fine but I do not recommend, make sure you put a cookie sheet underneath the muffin tins to catch the gooey filling that spills over the edge. Also if you don't have a 12x9 pan that's very tall, use a pan underneath that as well. Also, depending on your oven, you may want to leave them in a little longer than 20 minutes just to give them a bit of colour. Just make sure you keep an eye on them! Great recipe, highly recommended, thank you to whoever put this up!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe that doesnât require a bread machine. Any time I make these, people RAVE over them. I put them in a buttered 9x13 glass pan instead of muffin tins. I usually make the rolls the night before and put them in the refrigerator overnight to slow rise. In the morning I set them out for a few minutes and then put them into the oven WITHOUT preheating it. I turn the oven on at 375 and they always rise perfectly while they cook. I make icing with 1 cup powdered sugar, 1 1/2 tablespoons melted butter, 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract, and 1 1/2 tablespoons milk. I put the icing in a ziplock bag and in the refrigerator overnight. I set the icing out while the rolls cook, then cut a corner of the bag and drizzle it on the rolls when they are done in a cross-cross pattern.

My husband made this recipe today. He doesn't know much about baking, so the fact they turned out GOOD (not great) is probably an indication that the recipe is fine. text:
Just made these this morning and they were delicious! I only made one alteration - I added about 3/4 c. more flour, because I didn't knead by hand (I used my mixer with the dough hook). It needed a little more flour to "climb the hook" and clean the bowl. The balance of butter, sugar, and cinnamon in the filling was great - they weren't too sweet. The flavor was excellent! On the recommendation of others, I did put a rimmed baking sheet under my muffin tin, to catch drips. Oops, I lied - I made two alterations; I used butter instead of margarine.

text:
This was very easy to work with other than due to a mistake on my part. I used 1C bread flour and the rest white whole wheat because I don't buy AP flour. I used the stand mixer for the mixing and kneading. I misread the instructions and melted the butter for the filling and it made a total mess. I lost a lot of filling out the ends and when rolling because it was too liquid. This made it very hard to cut and get into the muffin tins so the results were less than even. However, they turned out fine and I will definitely try these again. I was surprised how easily the popped out of the muffin tin and had fully expected them to stick but very little of the filling leaked out.EDIT:3/12/13  Tried these again as planned and they are a huge mess as written.  Perhaps it's written for jumbo muffin tins but the center of the roll rises up in a cone shape and the filling leaked over (and under) making a big smokey mess. They taste really good right out of the oven and came out of the tins fine but I would not use a muffin tin again.

text:
These cinnamon rolls were very good!  The kids and myself loved them.  My only complaint is the instruction for using a muffin pan.  The filling tends to bubble out causing a sloppy mess on the tin and drips onto the bottom of the oven. I almost got smoked out of my kitchen by the sugar mix that caught fire. Some of you might think to put a cookie sheet under to prevent that, but as an inexperienced cook, it wasn't on the 'how to' so I didn't do it.  Next time I will use a pan and cook them longer to prevent such an occurance.

text:
These were very good for the 90 minutes it took.  Actually I had baked a Paula Deen recipe I found on the internet a couple days before and these tasted better, but the actual bread part was not as good as the Paula Deen ones which had two separate times to rise.  So if you have time, do the two risings, and use this recipe.  I think why we liked it much better than the Paula Deen was that this one uses brown sugar and Paula Deen uses white sugar.  The brown sugar has the best flavor but the 2nd rising is what makes the lightest and fluffiest cinnamon rolls

Display Name:
Dan Wood

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6129873.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this tonight and wish I had put a cookie sheet under them while baking or baked them in a pan. The sugar mixture gets pushed up and out as the rolls expand. It dripped down onto my oven (pain in the butt I have to clean it now) and nearly caught fire. Smoked out the whole house. I wish I had read the reviews earlier as others have had the same problem. The recipe should be re-written.
Also, I added the raisins and the rolls, although fluffy and soft, are too sweet to eat. I will make these again but use 1/8 cup of sugar in the dough and make 1/2 as much cinnamon goo, omit the raisins, and bake in a pan.
I also will roll the dough out to a 24"x 30" sheet before rolling. The recipe says to roll it out to a 12x9 rectangle but at that size mine was about 3" thick still.

text:
I made a few substitutions... almond milk instead of regular milk, butter instead or margarine, Stevia instead of sugar and coconut sugar instead of brown sugar and it still came out AMAZING!!!! My family begs me to make these all the time. Something I have found that puts them WAY over the top is that if you are going to make icing for them, instead of vanilla extract add butter flavor...Seriously to die for! I do think they are a little dry the next day but if you reheat them in the microwave for about 10-15 seconds per roll it solves that problem.

country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls were very easy and relatively tasty for the effort.  They weren't quite as rich and satisfying as another recipe I have, but that recipe takes almost all day to make.  I might try adding another egg yoke and using brown sugar (and increasing the amount slightly) in the dough itself, to see if that deepens the flavor a bit more.  Also, a large portion of the cinnamon filling melted out of the rolls when baked.   Maybe that is why the recipe says to put them in individual muffin tins to bake, which admittedly I did not do.  But if you are looking for an easy, quick, almost fool-proof home-made cinnamon roll recipe, I would recommend this one.

Fantastically easy recipe! I was looking for a fast recipe that is delicious and this is it.  I used a 9x13 pan. I added nuts on the inside as well as the butter/sugar mixture but also poured a nut mixture over the top before baking(1/2 c of d. brown sugar, 1/4 c soft butter and a capful of van flavoring, put in micro until melted) they tasted just like the ones in the mall! The cook time for me was exactly 20 minutes. They came out brown, soft and yummy. Thanks for the recipe, this is a keeper!

text:
So easy and delicious!  My dough seemed a little sticky at first but when I rolled out I used parchment paper and it rolled out just fine.  It is really cold right now so I had to soften my butter in the microwave for the filling.  I ended up melting it and pouring it over the rolled out dough before sprinkling the sugar/cinnamon mixture on top.  this worked out fine, though the butter ran over the edge a little bit.  Cooked in foil pan b/c I don't have a muffin tin.  Came out beautiful!  I have limited baking supplies so I eyeballed the salt, but I think it could have had some more.  It would have been nice to have a little saltier dough to go with the really sweet filling.  Still, enjoyed by the entire family!

text:
Excellent recipe and I was glad to find one that doesn't use a bread machine, because I don't have one.  I followed as written except that I used a 9x13" pan and they turned out nicely.  I see the advantage of using the muffin pan since they won't stick together.  I think the step where you let the rolls rise for 30 minutes could have been omitted, because mine didn't rise at all and they do plump up  nicely in the oven.  I used a powdered sugar/butter/milk/vanilla extract glaze for icing.  Yum!

text:
i tried this recipe this morning, and wondered if I should follow the instructions and put the yeast in with the flour mixture as opposed to dissolving it in the warm milk

i followed the recipe and mixed the my active dry yeast in with the flour and it didn't 'dissolve' into the dough - i could see the tiny yeast balls whilst kneading, I proceeded baking and it looked pretty ok but inside was dense and sort of like dry bread pudding... still edible...

i will try this again but will mix the yeast in with the warm milk before mixing it into the flour...

text:
Absolute perfection!  I've been baking for many many years and this is one of the easiest, yummiest cinnamon roll recipes I have come across.  I double the recipe, knead for 5 minutes in my mixer, used two 9" x 12" pans and topped with just a little bit of cream cheese icing (We enjoy the bread taste more than the sweet). I've made them 3 times now and each time they have been a family favorite. Left overs cut in half make for wonderful cinnamon french toast :)

text:
My best friend and I made these last Sunday for a trat, and they were amazing!!! I had to subistitute brown sugar for white sugar becasue we were out, but they turned out just fine! These took more than 90 minutes, but were so worth it. One hint though? FOLLOW THE RECIPIE! PUT THEM IN MUFFIN CUPS! I was an idiot and didn't. They were still really good, but the yummy sugar and cinamin oozed out the bottom and hardened into the worst hard candy I have ever tasted. We scraped the bottoms off, and tried the last half in the muffin cups. MUCH better. Also, they do expand A LOT in the oven, so don't worry if your rolls are small! :) Yum!

text:
Super easy and super yummy! I used whole wheat flour and turned out perfect. It was a bit sticky to knead but I just keep on adding flour while kneading until it came to a nice dough (it will never be smooth with whole wheat). Also, I let it rest it rest after lining up in baking pan for 2 hours because I wanted to bake them right before we sat for dinner. Result: warm, soft rolls for dessert. Had it with choc sauce.
Love this! thank you for the recipe, GD!

These are excellent! I only made a few changes. Instead of instant rapid yeast. I used active yeast. I had to dissolve it in the 1/4 water (warm) for 5 minutes instead of adding the yeast directly in the dry ingredients. Also I didn't use the entire sugar/butter filling since I also spread icing on top after it finished baking. Yummy!!

text:
Good and easy.  I made the recipe almost exactly as is (I used butter and added raisins).  And then put a glaze over it.  The only regret I have is not reading some more of the reviews first.  I put 6 of the rolls into a large muffin pan and the other 6 in a 11x7 pan (because I didn't have another large muffin pan);
The ones in the muffin pan did rise a little, the ones in the 11x7 flattened out then rose a little.  The ones in the muffin pans browned way too much, the ones in the 11x7 came out perfect.  Will probably make this again but use a 9x13 pan as others did.

text:
My daughter, 15, who never cooks said this morning, "I want to make cinnamon rolls". We never made before so I printed this recipe since it said 90 min. and looked fairly easy. Followed recipe exactly. However, used a 9x13 glass pan spacing the 9 rolls so not quite touching. Also she wanted frosting so we got from recipe called "Clone of Cinnabon". Rolls ended up big and fluffy like 4-5". I read review that had problems with the dough not rising, could maybe water been too cold or the milk cooled down to much and yeast didn't activate??? After we added the warm milk the dough definitely started to look alive! By the time the oven was preheated they had expended in the pan quite a bit. Grew even more during baking. When 20 min. were up, they looked perfect touching the sides of pan and each other. Moved rolls to a serving plate, then spooned any melted filling left in the pan over the rolls so not to waste. Topped with frosting. YUMMMM!!! These were melt in your mouth with a little bit of crunch and the best thing I think I have ever tasted! My daughter could not even finish one because she said it was so sweet. I think the frosting looked nice drizzled on top but maybe was overkill on the sweetness. But that's good because then we won't eat too many!  Next time I will make w/o adding any frosting and maybe even try a little less brown sugar in the filling. Thanks GOOFYDEBBIE for a great first experience making cinnamon rolls w/my daughter!

I added chopped pecans and they are best when Dark brown sugar is used. I also added extra cinnamon. I didn't use baking cups, just placed them close together in a 9x12 baking dish and they are the best! Topped them with cream cheese icing and WOW

text:
These cinnamon rolls turned out very pretty. They rolled up very nicely and looked like they'd come from a bakery when they were done. However, I'd have to say they were sort of dry. I had a feeling they would be somewhat dry before I even baked them, because the recipe only called for 1 package of yeast. I have tried other cinnamon rolls recipes before, which also used only 1 bag of yeast and came out sort of dry. However, these tasted pretty good. I did added some frosting to spice up the sweetness. Some people might want to eat these without extra frosting, as they still taste great without it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this just as written, except for baking in a 9X13 pan.  The dough came together flawlessly, and I did not have to add extra flour like some.  I made this in my KA mixer, kneading for 5 minutes and then just having it rest in the same bowl.  It was one of the easiest doughs to roll out and cut.  But after 30 minutes, they were still pretty much the same size.  I waited another 10 minutes, but needed to bake since these were for my kids before school.  I popped them into the oven and hoped for the best.  Somehow, when these started baking, they rose up and looked like beautiful cinnamon rolls.  I have actually never had rolls that turned out so perfect looking in the pan.  And they taste just as great, if not better, than most recipes that take at least twice as long.  Will make these often.  Thanks!

I always forget to rate these! These were really good and quick. And lucky for me I had some cream cheese in the fridge and I made the cream cheese icing and frosted them. But oh my God! I made a mistake! I accidentally MELTED the butter (I used butter instead of margarine) instead of just letting it get softened. When I took out the butter from the microwave, my sister was telling me that it's usually not melted (the butter), and after they were baked, I looked at the recipe again and she was right!  No wonder why it was so messy to cut! (I did use thread though) I also put them in a 9x13 in. glass pan.. just put them together.. not far apart. Butter melted or not, the result was amazing. Definitely wish I could make them again if I wasn't lazy!

text:
YUM.  Delicious cinnamon rolls.  The dough for me was still quite sticky after adding the rest of the flour (total of 3 1/4 cups) so I added another 1/2 cup and then used a LOT of flour for dusting when I was kneading it.  Was worried this would make the dough dry, but it didn't at all.   I baked them in the muffin cups, but next time, I think I'll use the Pyrex 13x9. And as another user said, DEFINITELY put a tray under these, I didn't and they were dripping so much that there was a lot of smoke in my kitchen! They cooked in 15 minutes.

Well, these live up to their name, they do take almost exactly 90 minutes - start to finish.  That being said I feel there is too much filling, I know it's supposed to be gooey but for us it's just too much brown sugar, butter, cinnamon flavor.  The dough had almost a raw taste to it but it was cooked completely through.  I'm not sure I'll waste the ingredients by making this again, Id rather just do the real rise type of cinnamon rolls, using my bread machine.

None
text:
Wow! The dough for these cinnamon rolls is PERFECT. Soft, lightly sweetened, easy to knead, fluffy. It was my first time working with bread dough/yeast and it was easy for a beginner.   I knew I wanted to make them a bit more special, though, so I used the caramelized pecan topping from "Overnight Caramel Pecan Rolls" from this site, but other than that, I did not change a thing.  One note, though: I put these in the oven at 375 F, hopped in the shower, and when I got out of the shower, I could already smell a hint of burning. I rushed to the kitchen and checked on the rolls and they were already done after 12 minutes! Next time, I'll either lower the baking temperature or just take them out early. Thank goodness they weren't actually burnt - these were delicious.  Note - they did take me 2 hours to make (not counting baking time). I don't think that's all just because I'm slow!

text:
These are the BEST in the world!  For years I have tried to master the cinnamon roll!  But always to fall short- you see they weren't like the cinnamon rolls my husband and I remembered in junior high.  They were the ones I have always tried to duplicate.  Well the first time I tried this recipe, my husband wasn't home until after I left to bring them to a potluck.  Well when I came home my husband put up a sign on the door that said, "YOU ARE THE CINNAMON ROLL QUEEN!"  I still have that sign because it is on the back of this recipe!  My family loves these!  I did everything in my Kitchen Aid mixer.  The secret is to knead in the mixer and you want the dough to be in the shape of a full water balloon. I omitted the raisins and made a cream cheese icing to put on after baking.

Ok, I don't understand the other reviews that said these were not as good as the recipes that took a longer time to prepare. These were awesome. text:
I was worried they wouldn't rise well since the recipe doesn't specifically proof the yeast, so I let the warm milk and flour mixtures sit together for a bit before I added the egg. I also let the cut rolls sit longer to rise. The dough turned out really great - moist and soft. My filling was good, but a little hard. It was probably because of my own adaptation to spread the margarine on the dough and then sprinkle the sugar/cinn mixture over top. I think the margarine/sugar ratio wasn't quite right. I think if I follow the recipe more closely next time I'll be fine. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
These were very good, the way I made them I would consider it a 4 start recipe but I changed it up a bit so it's only fair to give it a 5 because I think recipe as is would have been a 5.    I made it in a round pan and I think it didn't give them enough room.  I had a difficult time getting them to cook in the center.  Outside ones were very good but the inside ones were doughy and the filling was liquidy.    I will try again because they tasted great but I would try on a cookie sheet or in muffin pans as listed.    I would also use less butter because it made the filling run out of the rolls and added to the gooeyness.  The taste was great and the dough was easy to make for someone who doesn't make dough that needs to rise.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these rolls last night, my son ate 3 of them.  These were easy, almost too easy!  I made only one change to the dough recipe.. I substituted almond milk for regular milk. We like ooey gooey rolls, so I melted a topping of 1/2 cup butter, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup sugar, and 1/2 cup vanilla ice cream while the rolls were proofing.  I poured the topping over the rolls and baked for about 18 minutes.  This made the rolls very decadent!   I would recommend using a pan instead of a muffin tins.  Also, make sure you use a pan underneath to catch the overflow.. and they will overflow!  Thank you for such a great recipe!

This is crazy - a 5-star cinnamon roll that even *I* can make!  Thought maybe I had screwed it up when it didn't rise much during 30 minutes. I'll make the adjustment in my next batch.  And the way the pan is emptying, I'd better get started on that 2nd batch right now!  Thanks for such an easy recipe for something I am so proud to serve!

text:
Simply AWESOME!!...My 5 1/2 yr old son LOVED these.The only changes I made was, instead of using margarine, I used butter,and did not mix it with the cinnamon and sugar. I smeared the softened butter over the dough,then sprinkled the cinnamon/sugar mixture over the butter. I also rolled it out to about a 15x11 inch rectangle. That made 16 cinnamon rolls.This recipe is definitely a keeper for my family.

text:
PHENOMENAL CINNAMON ROLL RECIPE!!!!!!!  THANK YOU, GoofyDebbie!  :-)  I have been looking for a recipe for cinnamon rolls for two years, and THIS is it!  I will never go back to those inferior recipes that turn out such hard rolls.  These make moist, gooey rolls, and they are so easy to make.  Following the recommendations in other reviews, I baked them together in a 9 x 13 pan instead of individually in the muffin tin.  After baking I spread a thin layer of sugar icing: 1 cup powdered sugar, 1 tsp. vanilla, and just enough milk for the consistency you want.  Absolutely fantastic cinnamon rolls.  I've got some yummy in my tummy!

None
text:
These are well worth the time it takes to make them.  I followed the recipe exactly and they came out wonderfully.  I didn't add any frosting and I can't say that we missed it.  They were perfect plain.  They rise up beautifully and are really gooey, but a perfect balance of chewy outside & gooey inside.  I've made these twice, both successfully.  I didn't use a muffin pan the second time around since they ended up rising too much and exploded out of the wells.  I used a baking dish the second time around and that worked out much better.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best small quantity dough recipe I have found. A couple of things to keep in mind: Know your weather and oven. Our dough yesterday was mixed in a Kitchenaid Mixer and needed only 6 cups of flour. And that was plenty. Flour amounts can change with the humidity. Also keep in mind all ovens are different. For the filling I simply brushed the dough with melted butter, sprinkled some brown sugar to cover and sprinkled cinnamon. Then I rolled the mixture a bit to seal it on the dough.. Also baked this in a 9x13 pan in a convection oven at 350 for about 13 minutes. Then glazed the top a bit when still warm. Excellent buns!
