text:
Fabulous recipe!  I let my dough rise a little in the pan before I baked them, and it seemed to add the fluffiness.  I also just spread the butter on the dough after rolling, combined the sugar and cinnamon, and then sprinkled on top. Since my husband wanted something close to cinnabon, I doubled the amount of sugar and cinnamon used here, and whatever didn't get sprinkled in the rolls got sprinkled on top. Everyone thought these were delicious!

text:
Wow!  That was a rewarding project and I would highly recommend these rolls as a Sat morning activity with your kids.  I followed the recipe exactly except that I didn't put them in muffin pans, just a normal rectangular dish.  They began to rise and burst over the edges of the pan, again, kids would probably love making these with the help of an adult.  I did add a cream cheese frosting at the end which was worth it, they look fantastic and taste just as good!  My experience is that one package of a light cream cheese, with a splash of vanilla and adding powdered sugar to taste is perfect (and healthier than 2 c. of sugar plus butter.)  Oh, last thing, I found the short video on 'all recipes' showing how to prepare the rolls very useful, I would highly recommend it!  Happy baking!

text:
Yummy pretty much sums it up. Recipe was very easy to follow and carry out. I did add 1tsp more cinnamon though cause I didn't think it smelled cinnamony enough, and placed them in an 11x9 pan. Great texture and flavor, will defiantly make again. I did bake them in a pan and just used thread to cut them into rounds and had no trouble with bubble over. Thanks
.

For those having problems - if your dough does not rise, there was a problem with your yeast or liquid temperature and if your dough is sticky, add more flour - baking is a mixture of art and science and sometimes you need more flour and sometimes you need less.

text:
This was a good recipe to learn how to make the rolls, but I'll make some changes in the future. It was my first roll, so I stuck to the recipe. Husband loved them, but to me, they were lacking sweetness (weird, I know). They tasted more like bread than gooey cinna rolls. Next time I'll chill the rolled dough before cutting (it was a mess!!). I'll also add nuts before rolling. These can't be eaten without icing (not part of recipe), and I made the cream cheese icing from another post, which turned out too buttery -- needed more powdered sugar.  I too made them as one in a 9x12 pan instead of muffin tins, which was good, but ended up cooking too long and kinda hard on top and bottom.  Good base recipe with a few tweaks.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy!!!!
Regarding the muffin tins, instead of making 12 rolls, I made 24. Once I started to put the dough in the muffin tins, I noticed they were practically full already, and needed to double and bake. Then I read reviews that some of the filling had overflowed on some cooks, or pooled at the bottom. So, I cut each roll in half vertically and just pinched the edges--same thickness, just smaller diameter. After rising and baking, I had 24 beautiful muffin-sized rolls with no overflow and VERY minimal filling at the bottom of the tins. 
Very nice presentation.

These were great...I changed the recipe by letting the dough rise twice (once after kneading and then once again after I shaped them into rolls) I did add pecan pieces to the center cinnamon mixture.  I also just put them in a 9x13 parchment paper  glass pan.  They did burn a little so I reduce the heat to 325, but my oven cooks hot so It could be that.  The dough itself turned out very light and airy...I topped the rolls with homemade cream cheese frosting and they are perfectly gooy! great recipe.

text:
This was my first time making cinnamon rolls, and they came out AWESOME.  Im so proud. The hardest part was rolling up the dough with all the filling, a bunch fell out and i got a hole in the dough and it started oozing out.. but other then that it was fine. They came out perfect and oh so pretty.  I used floss to cut mine too, works great and fun too.  I made a glaze topping for mine, just made it up, it tasted real good on it.

just put a half a cup of milk in a pot, heated it and added some margarine, about 2 tblspoons then put powdered sugar until it was the right consistancy.  probably about 1.5-2 cups.  

YUM YUM YUM.

text:
This recipe is alright. I think there are better cinnamon roll recipes out there. I had a real tough time trying to roll the dough with the sugary spread in it.. most of it oozed out the ends. Instead of a muffin tin I put them in a pan, I think thats the solution if you don't want "muffin" cinnamon rolls. I topped mine with a cream cheese frosting. I probably won't make them again, but this is a good and easy recipe for those looking to make cinnamon rolls.

text:
I did not put these in muffin cups as indicated, instead I just placed them on a cookie sheet to bake.  They definitely do not need to bake for 20 minutes... I cooked them for 16 and that was way too long.  Overall, they were pretty good, although I thought they were a little cake-like in texture... might be better if they had not cooked for so long.  They taste was really very good... a lot like Cinnabons if you can find a way to make them not so cake-like.  I also added a cream cheese frosting, which they definitely needed!

These weren't bad at all for being 90-minute rolls.  I do prefer a different kind of roll, but I would definitely make these again if I needed something quick.  I didn't have milk so I used 1/2 cup of half and half and 1/4 cup of water to make up the required 3/4 cup of milk.   I also took a previous person's recommendation to make the glaze from the Overnight Cinnamon Rolls I.  That made it really scrumptious.

This recipe was good, but could do with a few improvements.  The rolls have a better texture, if most of the sugar mixture is put in the bottom of the pan (like sticky buns.) The addition of nuts adds a dimension to the flavor.
